title: Senators stop Sid, but not Penguins | Hockey | Sports | Toronto Sun
text:
PITTSBURGH - The Senators were able to extend Sidney Crosby’s scoreless streak to four games, but they could not push the Pittsburgh Penguins to a similar drought.
And in looking tired and weak in their second of back-to-backers, they had a run of their own stopped dead in its tracks: The only team not to get shutout last season had its run of 128 games without putting up a goose egg, as Ottawa was blanked 2-0 Thursday night at Consol Energy Center.
Clearly, the Senators used up all their firepower in Wednesday’s 7-3 victory over the Blue Jackets.
“We’ve got to get more bodies and traffic and pucks to the net, create chaos and mayhem in front, score an ugly goal to kind of get us going,” bemoaned centre Kyle Turris. “That’s what we were missing tonight.”
The loss was the Ottawa’s in first regulation time on the road since Feb. 3 — a string that was snapped at 14-0-3 — and left the Senators with a 3-2-0 record coming out of the gate to meet the 2015-16 campaign.
The Penguins are now 1-3-0.
Meanwhile, Crosby has still yet to register a goal or an assist this season, equalling the second longest pointless stretch of his illustrious career, counting playoffs.
Only once has he gone five games without a point, and that was back in November, 2009.
But just as he struggled, so did the Senators.
“I think we were off,” Turris said of the attack, refusing to use the second game in 24 hours as a crutch. “We weren’t as crisp and executing as well as we could, but we play back to back’s the whole season, so it’s not really an excuse.”
Marc Methot thought his team was just flat.
“They did what they had to do ... they knew we were coming off a back to back on the road, and it’s always for the home team to take advantage of that, and they did,” said the Senators defenceman. “I still think we didn’t manage it as good as we could.
“When you don’t have your legs beneath you, you’ve got to use your head a little more.
Evgeni Malkin and Daniel Sprong had the Pittsburgh goals, while Marc-Andre Fleury stopped 21 shots for the shutout.
“It was a defensive battle,” said Craig Anderson, who made 34 saves in the Ottawa net. “We tried to keep them off the scoreboard as best we could. One goal was going to win tonight.”
Both power plays went 0-for-3, as the Penguins had a great opportunity to change that in the third. Mark Borowiecki was called for a delay of game penalty early in the period when he backhanded the puck over the boards — despite the vehement protests of coach Dave Cameron, who pointed out his defenceman was in the neutral zone when he shot.
The Senators couldn’t reverse the call, but did kill off the 1:21 of 5-on-3 they were left playing as Erik Karlsson was already in the box.
After a scoreless second period which saw the Senators outshot 16-6, the Penguins struck quickly in the second.
Malkin scored his 19th goal in 30 regular season meeting with Ottawa at the 23 second mark of the period took a puck shoved up the right wing boards by Patric Hornqvist and, with Erik Karlsson as the lone man back, fired a shot from the offensive zone circle between Anderson’s right arm and his body.
“It went through my six-hole there,” said Anderson. “It’s just one of those things ... he’s one of the best in the world, and when good players have a knack for scoring, they score. Make that save, different game? I don’t know.”
Methot was caught up ice on and couldn’t get back time to disrupt Malkin.
“We pinched and we still have guys back, it’s a routine play,” he said. “I think he got a little lucky on that shot too. At the end of the day, those are the breakdowns that kill you, and we’ve got to clean it up.”
Just 2:02 later, former Senator Matt Cullen set up rookie Sprong up in the slot for a shot that found the back of the net up high as Anderson tried to stack the pads. It was Sprong’s first NHL goal.
Shortly after that, Crosby was set up on a 2-on-1 but uncharacteristically missed the open side.
The Senators failed to take advantage of two power play chances in the middle period, the second of which began with 1:17 to go before the intermission. Before the horn sounded, Bobby Ryan, Karlsson and Turris all missed the net with point blank chances.
“One good thing is we’re beating the goalie,” said Anderson. “We just weren’t able to put it on net.
“We’re going to get our chances, we got our chances. It was one of those nights where our sights just weren’t on.”
The Senators were outplayed early in the first period, although while holding the territorial advantage the Penguins only had five shots on goal through nine minutes. Ryan had the Senators best when he was set up alone in front by Mike Hoffman, but Fleury made a nice shoulder stop.
Anderson came up big by making a save off a Kris Letang wraparound and then, after Ryan gave the puck to the Penguins on a 3-on-2 rush, when Pittsburgh charged back into the zone for more chances.
Turris had a close in chance with one minute, but Fleury made a good stop on him too.
“We just couldn’t capitalize off the rush,” said Turris. “It definitely would have made it a different game.”
Meanwhile, one Ottawa streak was continued, albeit a short one. For the second game in a row, Borowiecki laid a pounding on an opponent, this time thumping Bobby Farnham in the third period.
The Senators returned home after the game to prepare for Saturday’s visit by the Nashville Predators.
